Fields.DialogueText: Excuse me, mon Capitaine. Might I have a word?
Anything for you, Algérie. You know, you can just call me Captain.
Very well... Capitaine. I was hoping we could speak frankly about a few things. Assuming you have the time, of course.
Time is in short supply these days, but I'll give you as much as I can right now.
Merci. Mon... that is, Capitaine, if I might risk a minor offense -
Algérie, remember that short supply I was mentioning?
The point, oui. How does one go about requesting an order from your quartermaster? Do I go through you first, or...?
That's it? That's all you need to know? Just tell him what you want, say that the captain approves the transfer, and you're all set.
So I do have your approval?
Within reason, but you're the Belle. You have leeway. Get what you need and on with what's next, all right?
Oui, Capitaine. I think you will be pleasantly surprised!

Fields.MenuText: What did I just get myself into?
Explain.
I'll be the judge of that.

Fields.DialogueText: A much-needed break, Capitaine. I thought I'd assist.
Supplies for a little relaxation, Capitaine. Nothing licentious, I assure you.
Do not hesitate to ask about the requisition. I simply thought we could take some time for ourselves soon.
... Fair enough. I'm interested to see where this is going - but, for now, you're dismissed.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
It appears we are not yet rid of each other. We shall make the most of it!
Algérie, a word, please?
Oui?
I just received word from the quartermaster that our delivery of... let me quote this for you...  "five bolts of silk swatch, various colors" is inbound.
Ah, so soon? Merveilleux!
What's so wonderful about it?
It is what I wished to order from the quartermaster.
So I gathered. I mean, what is this for?
Oh, so simple. It's...
Hold that thought, we'll get back to it.
@BATTLE
So, Capitaine, about the order...

Fields.MenuText: Not now, Algérie. We have another type of emergency brewing.
I'm sorry, Algérie, but we're going to have to postpone this for a bit.
Fate has doomed us to miss this conversation for now, Algérie. I'm sorry.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, ah, oui, Capitaine. I understand.
At your leisure then, Capitaine.
Then I shall tell them to spin more thread for the next time, Capitaine.
*ALARM*
In truth I'm a little afraid to imagine it.
Precisely why you will find it helpful. Leave it to me!
Algérie, a moment?
You, Capitaine? You may have several.
As many as I can spare. Now, then -
No need to fret. We can make time.
I... okay, anyway, I received this invitation from you and...
Ah, good, it arrived.
Weren't you the one who slipped it under my door in the first place?
But of course! How else would it have gotten there?
I... Can we just move on, please?
As the capitaine wishes.

Fields.MenuText: Truth be told, the Captain wishes for a cold washcloth for this headache.
Were it that simple, Algérie, were it that simple.
The Captain wishes for many things but rarely receives them.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, finally, something I can do for you! Allow me...
Ah, but your wish is my command, Capitaine.
Perhaps the capitaine is wishing for the wrong things?
Um... right... okay. Before we go any further, about the invitation?
Shall we continue this later, Capitaine? We have all the time in the world.
Let's see that we do.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
That's it. No more interruptions.
I agree. Would the capitaine care to follow me for a few moments?
Lead the way.
Thank you. It's just around this corner, actually.
What is... Wait, what have you done with this broom closet?
I transformed it into a home.
Home? This looks like a silk tent.
Oui, Capitaine. May I invite you in?
Would we both fit in there?
I might have made a few adjustments to the space in order that we could.

Fields.MenuText: You better not have damaged my ship.
Now that's a trick worth knowing about!
Are you saying you altered the dimensions of my ship without my permission?

Fields.DialogueText: Mon dieu, no! Nothing so impressive. And do remember, I am this ship.
And not one easily repeatable, truth be told.
Well, when you put it like that, it sounds much more impressive than it is. And do remember, I am this ship.
Care to explain?
Put simply, I stole a bit of room from the adjacent crawl spaces to create this. I figured if anything goes wrong in those areas, I don't need the space to help there anyway.
Okay, but I still don't understand why...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Silks, scents, and serenity, Capitaine. You'll thank me later!
Thank you for coming, Capitaine.
Your invitation was quite specific, Algérie.
Oui, but you didn't have to follow it. I appreciate your thoughtfulness.

Fields.MenuText: Thoughtfulness nothing - this is pure curiosity!
Well, I can't have the mysterious personification of my ship out of sorts with me, now can I?
Yeah, don't mention it... ever. Seriously, ever.

Fields.DialogueText: Either way, you're here.
No, no, that would be bad. I will refrain.
If you prefer.
So the reason I'm here is...
To be welcomed into my new home. Can I get you something? I have tea if you prefer it, or, of course, mazagran.
Never fails, does it?
Hardly ever. You know where to find me when the smoke clears.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Thank you for coming again. You don't know how much I look forward to these visits.
These visits? Algérie, I've come by twice now.
Yes, and both times were just lovely. Something to drink?
I'd enjoy a explanation over drinks.
Drink first, explanation second.

Fields.MenuText: No, explanation first, drink second.
I already live here. The hospitality is a little strange.
How about you just explain what's going on?

Fields.DialogueText: Tsk, tsk, Capitaine. I must insist it go the other way around.
Sometimes it is most needed in the home.
Come, Capitaine. Reason states that listening to those in a position of power is prudent.
Fine, fine, just get on with it.
Capitaine, I'd like to introduce you to my home. This is my place away from everything, the place where we can kick our feet up and unwind.
We? I have quarters if you'd like to visit.
No, you have a place where you can sleep and work. This is a place for the opposite.
For being awake and playing?
For being a person and not a capitaine.
I guess I see your -
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Shall we table the personhood for now?
I'll try and take it with me.
So you're saying I'm not relaxed enough?
How could you be, what with the war and the Morganas? I'm saying that a relaxed capitaine is a stable one.
So now you're saying I'm not stable?
Let's just say that for the health of this ship and its crew, I feel you could do better here.
And your suggestion is to spend time in a silk tent?
The beginning of my suggestion is just that, yes.

Fields.MenuText: You're crazy.
Okay, I'll bite.
I don't like how this is going, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps you could stand to be, as well. I know what I'm doing.
Thank you! You won't regret this.
It gets better, I promise.
For your sake, I hope so. Now, what...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Curses. Keep some of that tea there, Capitaine. In case you need it.
All right, let's get this over with.
I think this might be part of the issue. You want to move on to the next thing without taking any time to enjoy the moment.
Enjoy the... Algérie, you know we're in a war, right?
Everything is battle, Capitaine. What counts is how we treat the moments in between.
You said this was going somewhere. I hope we get there soon.
Right now, in fact. Here.
What's this?
A gift. This is a pouch of mint. It symbolizes hospitality and warmth, which is why I give it to you here in my home.

Fields.MenuText: A wonderful gift, truly.
Um, thanks, I guess.
Okay, gift given. I need to go now.

Fields.DialogueText: My 'wonderful gift' is a gesture, a welcoming into my life.
You may be lukewarm, but you are still welcome into my life.
You can leave if you like, but you can never leave the home in my heart.
This is getting strange.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
You have a home and a refuge aboard a ship, Capitaine. Have you ever been on one that returned the favor?
Well, no.
There is a first time for everything! I invite you to treasure it.
We'll have to win this fight first.
Capitaine, a moment?
Not now, Algérie.
But this will only be a moment.
I'm writing condolence letters to deceased crewmen's families. Is what you want more important than that?
Ah, no... I'm sorry.

Fields.MenuText: You should be.
Don't be. You couldn't have known.
Just give me my space.

Fields.DialogueText: And I am, truly.
Unless I had asked. Again, my apologies.
It is yours.
Fine, now go... please.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
There is a time and a place for everything. I'll leave you to this after the battle. My invitation remains open in the meantime.
Another invitation?
And another visit. So glad you could come down.
Is this going to be a 'thing' now?
Of course. This is my heritage, Capitaine; this is how we do things.
Your heritage? You're French.
I'm also a Berber, Capitaine. That is where this is from: my Berber side.
Your Berber side? What about the French Foreign Legion medallion?
I'm also French, Capitaine. One can be multiple things at the same time. We're both fighting for the French and for the world. Britain is fighting for itself, for us, and for the world.

Fields.MenuText: But we both agree, French first, yes?
As long as we fight for the INPF, it doesn't matter.
We're quibbling over insignificant things.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't mistake my heritage for my loyalty.
Against the Morganas, we are a single people.
Insignificant to you, but not so much to me.
Unfortunately for us, we aren't the ones with the final say. HQ rules, as always.
To a point, Capitaine, to a point. We still choose how we live, even if we can't choose where we live. I choose to live in my two worlds of French and Berber just as I...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All these interruptions... I don't know how you keep your composure.
My free moments are all the sweeter when I fight for them, Capitaine!
On the other hand, the sight of a burning Morgana is that much more cathartic.
Good day, Algérie. Nice to see you outside of your tent.
Please, Capitaine, you know I exist outside of the tent. Why the formality?
You tell me. You're the one who keeps trying to get me in there.
Is it strange to desire better relations with one's fellow man? I think not.
Neither do I, when it comes down to it. It's just... hmm... can I be honest with you?
Oui, please!

Fields.MenuText: The formality of the whole thing is just a bit off-putting.
I don't appreciate someone carving up my ship without my permission.
I've never had to deal with something so frivolous... no offense intended... before.

Fields.DialogueText: The formality of being in a makeshift tent created from bolts of silk?
I used the chain of command, Capitaine. It just never got as high as you.
None taken, but is it frivolous to celebrate one's homeland?
Look, when you put it that way...
If you'd like I could... well... I could take it down.
Oh, I didn't mean...
Merde!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Sounds like you could use some of that tea you lent me.
Gave, Capitaine, gave. I've got kilos of it. And a curse here and there can be just as therapeutic as a cup.
Ah, Capitaine, I'm so glad I caught you.
Caught me? You just saw me.
Oui, but I mean alone. I'm glad I caught you alone.
For what purpose?
To ask you about my tent. I never heard if it could stay or if you wanted it gone.
Ah, that.
Oui, that.
Of course it can stay.
Merci, Capitaine, merci!

Fields.MenuText: After all, we already paid for the silk.
Well, I wouldn't want to disappoint you.
Don't mention it. Seriously, don't tell the crew.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, well... you certainly know how to cheer a girl up.
And you haven't, you haven't. Merci, merci!
I can promise not to tell any more of them, but, eh... you know.
Now, if you'll excuse me...
Things to do?
You know me so well.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
That tea must be doing you some good.
How did you -
Just a guess, Capitaine, from your bearing. How wonderful to be right!
Another invitation?
It is the best way to get you down here.
You know I shouldn't be away from the bridge this long.
The men can handle your absence for a few minutes at a time. How else will they learn to live without you?
Why would you want them to?
Ah, no, you misunderstand me. What I meant to say is that they cannot learn and grow as crewmen unless you give them room to stretch.

Fields.MenuText: Yes, that's much better than encouraging my death.
They learn and grow by following my example.
Fair point, but battle isn't the best time to be alone.

Fields.DialogueText: Tsk tsk, Capitaine, don't be so dramatic.
And they maintain that example when you're out of sight.
Aboard me, they are never alone. Be calm, Capitaine.
Yes, well... you have your tent. If you'll excuse me?
But Capitaine, I invited you here for more than just a moment.
I understand, truly, but I have things to do.
Another time then? Promise?
For you? I promise.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
And not a moment too soon...
Good to see you have returned.
A promise is a promise, though I have to ask - how is it you got here before me? I swear you were just behind me.
You know how I move in the ship, Capitaine. I can't be in two places at once, but I can move from one place to the next in the blink of an eye.
I should just have you run the ship then.
Oh no, Capitaine, don't say that!
I was only kidding, Algérie.
Good.

Fields.MenuText: I would never risk the lives of the crew with you at the helm.
We all have our jobs. I can't abandon mine.
It's not that you couldn't do it... I mean, could you?

Fields.DialogueText: Nor would I want you to!
You command, we follow!
Sadly, no. Again, I cannot be everywhere at once.
So, you asked me down here?
I thought I'd share some more tea with you. What did you think of the mint leaves?
We'll figure it out. Morganas inbound!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
They smell nice. I keep them on my desk.
Keep them there. I will show you how to drink it now.
You can make tea out of it? But it's not tea.
Herbal infusions are older than human history. Tea is simply the best known. There is a word for one thing becoming synonymous with everything like it...
What would you like?
I know you like the cold drinks, but I think I'm in the mood for something hot.
Oui. Name your desire.
That's a little too forward for me, Algérie.
Capitaine, I apologize. I shouldn't have -

Fields.MenuText: Another joke, Algérie, relax.
What, can't take a joke?
Hey, you opened this door!

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, good one!
Is that what you call a joke?
And now I'm shutting it!
Anyway... about that drink. I think I'll take some tea.
Oui. A matter of moments. Un, deux... et voila. Tea.
That is absolutely amazing.
Merci. One of the benefits of a friendly Belle.
I never doubted the benefits.
And you never will have cause to.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All that effort, and now it'll just get spilled.
Not if I have anything to say about it!
You know, I finally tried those mint leaves of yours. The flavor was like nothing I've ever had.
Do I know how to pick them, or do I know how to pick them?
Wait, did you hand pick these?
Just a saying, Capitaine.
But I have to ask, just where did you get these? I'm no spice expert, but these have to be top notch.
I am, and they are. Giving second-rate housewarming gifts is considered rude in my culture.
The Berber side of your culture?
Oui. Is that a problem?

Fields.MenuText: We've covered this. No, it's not a problem.
We've covered this. Your loyalty to the Fleet is never in doubt.
We've covered this. I don't have a choice but to accept it.

Fields.DialogueText: Then I'm glad it is settled.
I appreciate your candor and your acceptance.
I approve of honesty, but your bluntness is... abrasive.
Just so long as you understand that, we're settled. Now, can we discuss something more important?
You have something in mind?
You still haven't answered my question about the mint. Where did you get it?
It warms my heart to see you taking an interest in my interests, Capitaine. This particular leaf came from...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I'm tempted to cut out the middleman and eat it.
Patience, Capitaine. It will be waiting for us when we return.
And this one? What's this?
Saffron. It is difficult to harvest, so it's of course expensive.
And its symbolism?
As with everything, it means many things. For me, the primary symbolism is humility, which leads into equality. We can't be equal unless we are humble.
Liberté, égalité et fraternité, oui?
Oui!
If it is so expensive then... pardon the question... how did you get your hands on it?
A girl must have some secrets, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Not on this ship, no.
Fine, fine, I know better than to push by now.
Really? Really?

Fields.DialogueText: Then in that case, I don't remember.
Thank you for respecting my boundaries, Capitaine.
Oui. Oui.
I can't say as I like it, but perhaps a bit of mystery is sometimes needed. Just don't make a habit of it.
I promise.
And now if you'll excuse me, it's time for me to return to the bridge. Thank you for the tea.
Thank you for the company.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Thank me after the battle. Seems you're not rid of me quite yet.
I know that one without needing to taste it. It's clearly garlic.
Easily done, Capitaine. Care to venture a guess as to its symbolism?
Uh... repellant?
Protection, so close enough. You're doing well.
There's just something about this that's... I don't know... engaging. I mean, I never would have thought learning about spices would be so interesting, but there's a certain... um...
Pleasure?

Fields.MenuText: Okay, yes, pleasure. There's a certain pleasure that goes with it.
Not quite pleasure. More like satisfaction.
No, no, much more like a sense of completion, like I'm crossing something off a list.

Fields.DialogueText: That's good. It means you're enjoying your time.
Satisfaction is a positive. I'll take it.
Not as good as I'd like it, but still movement in a positive direction.
Perhaps we should take a clove or two with us to the bridge this time? Protect us from the evil Morganas?
Careful with your superstitions, Algérie, or you'll become a sailor at heart.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
And what little herb do you have for me today, Algérie?
Only the most profitable spice from the Dutch East India Company.
Easy. Ginseng.
Wrong. Cinnamon.
Really?
Oui, really. It was used for purification and entrance into the spirit world in many cultures.
You're not the only one who knows something about this, Algérie. Cinnamon was used on the phoenix's pyre to speed along its rebirth and resurrection.
Why Capitaine, you impress me.

Fields.MenuText: I should. I'm very impressive.
I shouldn't. I learned that when I was five.
You flatter me. I'll take it.

Fields.DialogueText: Now if only we could work in the humility as well.
As did all schoolchildren, I'm sure.
You were intended to.
I'm sorry, what was that? I couldn't hear you.
Nothing, Capitaine, nothing. Shall we continue after this engagement?
Oui.
Magnifique!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Algérie, do you have anything special for removing mechanical grease?
I don't believe so, no... though perhaps some simple salt and pepper would help rub it... oh my, what happened to you?
Minor grease explosion in the... you know, you don't want to know about it.
But your face!
It's fine, really. I'm not hurt. That's just the grease.
Oh, thank heavens. The capitaine cannot be hurt, not like that.

Fields.MenuText: Why Algérie, I didn't know you cared that much.
Yes, there are much better ways for the Captain to be hurt.
It's just grease, Algérie. Not a big deal.

Fields.DialogueText: I care about all my crew, Capitaine. Have no fear.
Don't go looking, Capitaine.
I simply can't stand to see my crew in pain.
But back to the original question... Nothing at all?
Nothing comes to mind.
All right, I'll be in my cabin. Scrubbing.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
You'll be on the bridge looking dignified for your battle scars.
Thank you. Scars don't come off, though.
But they do teach valuable lessons!
I'm just not used to seeing ginger shaved that way. That's all I'm saying.
It dries well when separated but stays moist when with other layers. That's why I do it like that.
I wasn't attacking, just noting.
And can you note the symbolism of ginger?

Fields.MenuText: Easy - wealth.
Easy - success.
Easy - passion.

Fields.DialogueText: And success, and passion, and something more.
And wealth, and passion, and something more.
And wealth, and success, and something more.
Which would be what, exactly?
All of those are an outgrowth of power, which is the... forgive the pun... root of the symbolism of ginger.
No, I absolutely refuse.
To?
Forgive the pun. That was atrocious.
That is what makes it great! We will navigate the impasse.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
And this skirmish.
I've studied up on this one, Algérie. Rosemary sometimes symbolizes immortality, which is as you say an offshoot of fidelity.
You're mostly right, Capitaine. Fidelity is an offshoot of immortality. By remaining faithful to your partner or God, you live in them forever.
But only as long as they remain faithful in you.
Oui. Depressing, isn't it?

Fields.MenuText: Just a bit, yes.
Not in the least!
I haven't really thought about it much.

Fields.DialogueText: To think that the only way to live forever is through others...
Truly? There I would have thought we were of one mind. Surprising.
About your own death? In the middle of war?
It's not as simple as that and you know it.
Nothing is ever simple, Capitaine, but some things are clear.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Clear and present danger.
Clear path to overcoming it.
You know, I haven't received an invitation for days.
You haven't needed one. You have learned to come down here on your own. I'd say that means I've been successful.
As much as I'd like to argue with you, I can't. In fact, if I were being perfectly honest...
... Which you should be by now!
... I'd say that I've come to actually enjoy these times. I never really thought I needed extra relaxation, but this... this has done something good for my soul.
Questions of the soul aside, I'm glad you've found an outlet. I promise you that the crew have noticed it as well. Have you seen them relax more around you?

Fields.MenuText: That's simply seeing what you want to see.
Now that you mention it, they are a bit more relaxed, aren't they?
Things are running smoothly, that's all I care about.

Fields.DialogueText: Or perhaps you're refusing to see the truth before you?
They are. They take their cues from the top, as you said before.
Then don't change anything, if it's working well.
Still, herbs and spices? If anyone found out...
They won't, not from me. And even if they did, would you care?
Well, let's just say... um...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I'd certainly be more at peace with it.
Because it brings you peace, and  that is all that matters. That and victory, for the moment.
About that question you asked me in the tent, about whether or not I would care...
Oui? Well, would you?
You know, some Japanese captains have little trees they trim to keep calm and seek perfection. I suppose this is something like that.
Something to take one's mind off the carnage. So you are satisfied?
I'm not going to trumpet it across the fleet, but I won't deny that I'm enjoying myself. No, I only wish... well...
Oui? Spit it out, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: I just wish there was more I could do to make others enjoy it as well.
Just, I don't know, let's keep this to ourselves after all.
If there's anything I can do to repay you for this, just let me know.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, but there is. I have an idea...
I respect your wishes, Capitaine. I had an idea...
I can tell you now if you don't mind. I have an idea...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Get it to me in writing. We're about to get busy.
I will do better, Capitaine. My presence will be as calming as the idea itself.
I'll bite - what was your idea?
No, no, now that I've had time to think...
Oh come now, we can't keep doing this. Don't make me... well, I don't beg, but I will ask with a sterner tone.
Hmm. We can't have that, can we? Very well. I had an idea... what if we were to arrange for a tea ceremony for the entire crew, one that would lift spirits and create, well...

Fields.MenuText: Liberté, égalité et fraternité?

Fields.DialogueText: Oui! You understand me so well. So, Capitaine, is this something we can do?
I think we might just manage it, yes.
Oh thank you, thank you, you're such a magnificent... um...

Fields.MenuText: Friend, one you can count on.
Friend, and perhaps... well... who knows what else.

Fields.DialogueText: And one I will count on, no less.
I look forward to finding out.

Fields.MenuText: Relaxation?

Fields.DialogueText: Naturally, but camaraderie is closer to what I had in mind.

Fields.MenuText: Satisfaction?

Fields.DialogueText: More than that, Capitaine. Determination. A sense of family and companionship.
